title: Polipo
text:
Polipo is a lightweight <a href="web%20cache">caching</a> and forwarding <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">web</a> <a href="proxy%20server">proxy server</a>. It has a wide variety of uses, from aiding security by filtering traffic; to caching web, <a href="Domain%20Name%20System">DNS</a> and other <a href="computer%20network">computer network</a> lookups for a group of people sharing network resources; to speeding up a <a href="web%20server">web server</a> by caching repeated requests. It can be configured to use on-disk cache and serve cached content when offline and perform various forms of content filtering.
To minimize <a href="Latency%20%28engineering%29%23Communication%20latency">latency</a>, Polipo both <a href="HTTP%20pipelining">pipelines</a> multiple resource requests and <a href="Time-division%20multiplexing">multiplexes</a> multiple transactions onto the same <a href="Transmission%20Control%20Protocol">TCP/IP connection</a>. Polipo is <a href="HTTP%201.1">HTTP 1.1</a>-compliant, supports <a href="IPv4">IPv4</a>, <a href="IPv6">IPv6</a>, traffic filtering and privacy-enhancement.
Polipo is <a href="free%20software">free software</a> released under the <a href="MIT%20License">MIT License</a>.
Polipo ceased to be maintained on 6 November 2016 due to the increasingly widespread use of encryption (i.e. <a href="HTTPS">HTTPS</a>) making caching proxies obsolete.
Design.
Polipo is designed to be used as a personal web cache or a web cache shared among a few users to boost internet access. Designed to be fast, lightweight and small, it is useful when the system resources for a larger proxy are unavailable. Because of this, it has been put to uses such as a tether on the <a href="OpenWrt">OpenWrt</a>.
GUI wrappers.
Natively, polipo comes as a highly specialized <a href="command-line%20interface">command-line interface</a> (CLI) software application, which requires commands to be typed on the <a href="Computer%20keyboard">keyboard</a> and parameters stored in <a href="Configuration%20file%23UNIX.2FLinux">configuration text files</a>. Alternatively, polipo allows <a href="User%20%28computing%29">user</a>s to run the program automated and non-interactively, such as in a <a href="shell%20script">shell script</a>. By starting a <a href="Graphical%20user%20interface%23GUI%20wrappers">GUI wrapper application</a> users can intuitively <a href="Human%E2%80%93computer%20interaction">interact with</a> polipo, start and stop it and change its working parameters, through graphical <a href="Icon%20%28computing%29">icon</a>s and visual indicators.

Limitations.
Polipo is limited to 2G or 4G file sizes on 32 bit systems which will cause errors when serving large requests.
